Situation1: Both have several free evenings this week and can choose any for a date.
Expectation2: Fix bugs and troubleshoot issues reported by users or QA
Situation2: A production outage traces back to a defect in their code and customers cannot access the service
Story:
I stare at my phone, rereading the message from my boyfriend: “Let’s pick a night this week for our date! I’m free any evening.” I smile, picturing us laughing over dinner, finally unwinding after our busy days. He’s been hinting that we haven’t had much time together lately, and I know he’s hoping for a night where I’m not distracted by work. I want that too—just us, no laptops, no notifications.

But then my work chat pings, and my heart sinks. There’s a production outage, and the root cause is a bug in my code. Users are locked out, and the support team is escalating. My manager’s message is clear: “We need you on this ASAP.” I feel the weight of responsibility settle on my shoulders. Customers are frustrated, and the team is counting on me to fix it—tonight, if possible.

I glance between my phone and my laptop, torn. I want to be present for him, to show him he matters. But I can’t ignore the crisis at work. My chest tightens as I try to figure out how to be both the girlfriend he deserves and the developer my team needs.
